intro: Euhaynaldia organensis, commonly known as the Organ Mountains holly, is a rare shrub native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its small, elliptical leaves that are typically covered in a fine, white pubescence. The plant produces clusters of small, white flowers in the spring, followed by red, fleshy berries that are an important food source for local wildlife. Euhaynaldia organensis thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it well adapted to its harsh desert environment. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
